data.text: Food Planning on Multiday Bicycle Tours: What Do You Eat?
Hi Everyone, I was wondering how yâ€™all deal with food on multiday tours. What to eat during a whole day. How much food to buy at once. Simple food to cook. Looking forward to all the experiences :)
Varies for different people I guess. Depends where you're going. Went through the Rockies, no shops for 5 days plus an emergency ration.
data.author: Daniel Murphy

data.text: It all depends on where you are & whatâ€™s available! If there isnâ€™t many shops I would carry more/extra High energy food is what you want You will be amazed on how many calories you will burn through
data.author: Ashley Burton

data.text: As mentioned before, it really depends on where you are touring. In Europe, you rarely need to carry more than a dayâ€™s worth of food, as you are going through villages frequently (depending on the route). If you are doing a backcountry tour, you might have to carry multiple days of food. One way to approach each dayâ€™s amount of food, is to decide how many calories you will need for the day. So, if you decide you need 3000 calories/day, then you plan your food accordingly. Itâ€™s always good to add emergency calories should things not work out, or you find you have underestimated your caloric needs.
data.author: Colleen Welch

data.text: How do you convert between metric calories and imperial calories?
data.author: Justin M Short BA

data.text: A lot of things can be had at the grocery store and arenâ€™t in cans. Spam and tuna can be had in plastic packets not needing refrigerator. Mountain House beef stroganoff is always a go toðŸ˜Š
data.author: Bryan Lee

data.text: I bought a food dehydrator & make my own meals. I prefer fresh ingredients when I can get them, but I find the meals I dry tasty & also lightweight for packing. For snacks, beef jerky & nuts. Hard cheeses also keep quite well unless itâ€™s really hot weather.
data.author: Cheryl Leskiw

data.text: Need to plan your journey. Where / if you can re-stock. On my tours in the UK, there is always some town / village shop somewhere on route to re-stock. I like fresh food. Bacon can be carried at least a couple of days safely, Potatoes / onion / mushroom easily a week or more, Eggs are fine for ages but delicate, Canned food is heavy so carry less & re-stock where possible. Rice / Pasta etc is always a good back-up but i so booooooring! (Cept when doing a Chinese curry (with Potato if you can't keep meat that long). I make up spice mixes for authentic British Indian Resturant (BIR) curries and also carry Mayflower Chinese Curry Sauce Powder. If I have not found a 'Re-stock' to get fresh meat, I will use a small potato, diced to simulate 'lumps' (it works - trust me). Tip, a few small potatoes keep better than one large potato due to the 'cut'. Ask, and I will post a couple of recepies.
data.author: Nitty Knight

data.text:
https://youtu.be/qvLUYu0_0i4
Fuel Your Ride! Presentation
youtube.com
data.author: Steve Cardin

data.text: Donâ€™t plan on restocking at every stop at grocery stores/restaurants/convenience stores. I did that once and there were no places to buy food for two days. What I had planned on was closed. Luckily, I had some muffins and candy bars for energy. But, it left me feeling terrible. I will be making room on my next adventure for some real food.
data.author: Sheila Kitchen Irvin

data.text: This is a silly question. Tell us where you're going for God's sake. It's one thing if it's the Altiplano of Bolivia and quite another if it's the central UK.
data.author: Adie Mitchell

data.text: For touring pace I pack several days worth of food on the bike just in case I find some place I want to hang out for a while. I eat breakfast and then get off the bike for a meal every 4 hours or so, busting out the camp stove if necessary. At ultra pace I raid gas stations and grocery stores for a variety of things, salty, sweet, and bland, protieny, fatty, carby. Let your taste buds be your guide, take a chomp out of whatever youâ€™re hungry for every 15 minutes or so while youâ€™re in motion.
data.author: Justin M Short BA

data.text: I'm going on a 6,000 kms tour, and will be carrying x24 MREs for the first half, and then restock every few days when I go thru small towns or cities on the way back. Here's a picture of my bags, for 60 days. Ish. Trick is to evenly spread out your weight.
data.author: Jonathan Jolin

data.text: Dense high calorie food. I usually do oats for breakfast, then protein bars, dried fruits, nuts for snacks, for dinner brown rice with a can of tuna or something. I suppliment with plenty of coffee and pastry shop stops. I try to only carry what I need until the next resupply area, so I'm always checking ahead on my route a day or two and doing mental notes on grocery stores, cafes, pubs. Always carry a bit extra, "emergency food" I call it but really just one extra full meal incase I do something different than planned. D
data.author: Jason Roussel
Lawrence Bailey

data.text: Bobâ€™s Red Mill Scottish oats - soak to reduce cooking time. - with maple sugar, dried blueberries or Trader Joeâ€™s golden berry mix, dried mandarin sections, almond protein powder & reconstituted dried goats cream &/or dried almond or cashew milk. Repeat, alternating with with whatever can be found along the way. Dried hash brown potatoes carried in nalgene water bottles (bulky, but light weight - I ride a recumbent trike). & Reconstituted Dried fruit powders (assorted orange, pineapple, raspberry, strawberry, elderberry, &c.) in water bottles, lotsa plain water in bladders.
data.author: Will Taylor

data.text: ramen
data.author: Tony Allen

data.text: Depends on a lot of variables. Your dietary restrictions. If none than the limits of your location. If your bike packing vs touring I'd assume you are not always in a town or in urban areas. So at best you'll need a day or two but maybe just a night if you plan well. I guess it really comes down to a trip by trip basis in your region of choice.
data.author: Justin Serpico

data.text: To answer what I bring. I bring mostly high protein, high fat. I don't eat much Carbohydrate. Only about 50-75g a day and the bulk of my meal is breakfast and dinner. Lunch is only 400cal of snacks. Mostly caffeinated chocolate, cheese crisp, and protein in the form of meat bars (epic) or beef jerky. Maybe some olives or nut/seed butter. Or homemade nut butter protein bars. Breakfast is always the same: 16oz Starbucks bulk instant coffee with 20g collagen, 10g powdered MCT, 2TBSP (Equiv) heavy cream powder. + a protein shake which is 30g whey protein, 10g MCT, 12oz equivalent whole milk powder, and 2 tsp erythritol. Dinner is more of the same but in the form of bone broths and high fat protein dense soups. It all works out to 120g fat, 180g protein, 60g carbs. For about 2000 calories, or a deficit of about 1000 calories most days.
data.author: Justin Serpico

data.text: Eat all day, grazing works for me, especially on 250/300km days
data.author: Chris Andrews

data.text: I just bring what I enjoy normally that's quick and easy, preferably high protein and 1.5x extra calories - nut butters, dried fruit/leather, home-dehydrated vegan meals for camp dinners, muesli bars, electrolyte packets (LMNT), tea for mornings.
data.author: Carter AL

data.text: I stopped carrying a stove a long time ago to save space and cleanup time. I typically buy a bunch of clif bars , assorted protein bars, trail mix , dried fruit snacks, etc from trader joes and add nuun tablets to my water. I also really like those energy gummies clif makes.
data.author: Galen Campbell

data.author: Broom Wagon

data.text: Plan ahead so you know where shops are and their opening times. Beware of local closing days (eg Sundays in some countries). While itâ€™s great not to carry an excess of food itâ€™s good to have a back up meal, packet of noodles, buried in a pack just in case.
data.author: John Knapp
